unnormalised: So, you wanna be a champion, huh? Whether it's cricket like Virat Kohli or wrestling like the Phogat sisters, raw talent only takes you so far. It's the training, my friend, the relentless grind of daily drills, that separates the good from the legends. Let's talk training regimens, desi style.
normalised: So, you wanna be a champion, huh? Whether it's cricket like Virat Kohli or wrestling like the Phogat sisters, raw talent only takes you so far. It's the training, my friend, the relentless grind of daily drills, that separates the good from the legends. Let's talk training regimens, desi style.

unnormalised: First off, forget those fancy, Instagram-worthy routines. Real training is about discipline, consistency, and listening to your body. Remember Kavita Devi, the wrestler? She didn't start with power cleans in a state-of-the-art gym. Her foundation was built on years of dangal training in the village akhara, wrestling in the mud, building strength the old-fashioned way.

She didn't start with power cleans in a state-of-the-art gym. Her foundation was built on years of dangal training in the village akhara, wrestling in the mud, building strength the old-fashioned way.

unnormalised: A typical regimen, especially in India, often starts early. Think dawn yoga sessions, surya namaskars to greet the sun, followed by a light but protein-rich breakfast – maybe a bowl of sprouted moong and some chai. Then it's off to practice, whether it's batting practice at the MCA stadium in Mumbai, or running laps around the JNU campus in Delhi.

Then it's off to practice, whether it's batting practice at the M C A stadium in Mumbai, or running laps around the J N U campus in Delhi.

unnormalised: The specifics vary, of course. A marathon runner like Milind Soman would focus on long, slow distance runs, gradually increasing mileage. We're talking 60-80 km weeks, broken up with tempo runs and interval training. A kabaddi player, on the other hand, needs explosive power and agility. Think agility drills, plyometrics, and countless hours spent raiding and tackling on the mat.

unnormalised: Strength training is crucial across the board. Whether it's lifting weights in a gym (many have expanded to 1500 sq ft areas), or doing bodyweight exercises like push-ups, squats, and lunges. Think core strengthening – planks, Russian twists – all those fun exercises that build that rock-solid foundation. Dr. Sharma, the team physician, always emphasizes the importance of proper form to prevent injuries.
normalised: Strength training is crucial across the board. Whether it's lifting weights in a gym (many have expanded to one thousand five hundred square feet areas), or doing bodyweight exercises like push-ups, squats, and lunges. Think core strengthening – planks, Russian twists – all those fun exercises that build that rock-solid foundation. Doctor Sharma, the team physician, always emphasizes the importance of proper form to prevent injuries.

unnormalised: Nutrition is another key component. Forget junk food. We're talking a balanced diet rich in protein, carbohydrates, and healthy fats. Think dal, roti, sabzi, and plenty of fruits and vegetables. Supplementation might be necessary, but it's always best to consult with a qualified nutritionist. Even the local mithai shop owner, Sharmaji, would advise against too much sugar!

unnormalised: Rest and recovery are just as important as the training itself. This is where many athletes fall short. Getting enough sleep – 7-8 hours minimum – is crucial for muscle repair and recovery. Active recovery, like light stretching or swimming, can also help reduce muscle soreness. And don't forget the power of a good massage! Rs. 500 well spent, I say.

unnormalised: Ultimately, the best training regimen is the one that works for you. Find what you enjoy, listen to your body, and don't be afraid to experiment. And remember, Rome wasn't built in a day. It takes time, dedication, and a whole lot of hard work to become a champion. Jai Hind!
